segments.text: impressed me so that when I needed an assistant I thought about him, wrote him and offered him a job to come there as an instructor in the mechanical engineering laboratory and it was something that he wanted to do so he came and we had a good relationship there he gradually promoted himself in the department and then
Just like me in the middle 30s, he wasn't too happy there.
Things changed during the Depression, you know.
If you didn't live through it, you didn't know just what the conditions were.
Anyhow, he decided to go to the University of Michigan and take some graduate work, and that's what he did.
And they kept him on the staff up there.
He was just good enough so that they hired him.
And he didn't come back to Kentucky.
In the early spring, early summer, late spring of 1946, that young man, he wasn't too young by that time, that I had hired in the middle 20s, called me on the telephone.
And he says, Prof.
I've got some research work to do here which you may be interested in."
He knew that I had been doing research.
I had a reputation as a research engineer somewhat better than that of a college professor.
And he said, I've got some research.
I thought maybe you'd like to help me.
And he went on.
We talked about it.
It was some work that he had to do for the Army Ordnance Department located there in Detroit.
And he offered me a salary.
He mentioned a salary, which was almost twice what I was getting at Kentucky.
And since I was beginning to get a little bit tired of that work I was doing there for the agriculture department, couldn't see much future to it, I just accepted the job.
So I went to Michigan and Ann Arbor.

When we saw that it was going to take too long to get some of the equipment we needed for this research project, then the department head up there and others just got together and they said, well, why don't we extend this project over a period of two years?
In the meantime, we'll give O'Bannon some teaching.
So they did that.
I got three fifths of my salary for teaching and two fifths for research.
That is to say, the M.E.
department paid me three-fifths of my salary for teaching.
That's two courses of thermodynamics.
And the research institute paid me two-fifths for doing the research.
And that went on for two years.
And it took that long to complete the work.
I barely finished it.
What was the nature of the work?
It had to do with what they called vehicular equipment.
It never was

spelled out specifically in any of the reports it was what the army department labeled as restricted and the only report that ever came from it was the one that i wrote and put into the research institute there which was transferred to the army and if they followed their practice they kept it secret it retained the lubrication of
bearings on army tanks.
During the war, they would order oil, and they didn't know whether they would get oil for the Sahara Desert or oil for Alaska.
They took two different kinds of oil, and what they wanted to use in Alaska, I'm just using that as an illustration, should have been sent to Sahara, or it wasn't the kind of job
all they needed for low temperature operation.
And what they got in Africa was the oil they needed for high temperature.
What they were looking for was one oil that they could use any place over the world.
And that was my job.
They would send me all kinds of lubricating oils for these bearings on these tanks.
And my job was to find out the characteristics of those oils and eventually, if possible,
Find one R that could be used anywhere in the world regardless of the temperature.
Desert, North Pole, or whatever.
And that I did.
That was my job.
And I think I did a good job.
But nobody will ever know because it was never published.
It was restricted.
Army secret.
Hey, you left there.
What was the circumstances of your coming to College Station?
There again, you asked for a story.
Professor Crawford here was head of the M.A.
Department at that time.
He wrote to the University of Michigan inquiring about somebody up there who'd come here and be on his staff.
And his specifications fitted my specifications.
And when this friend of mine,
who learned about it indirectly.
He called me on the phone.
He says, prop, she says there's a man down in Texas who's looking for a college professor.
Well, this young man and my friend in Michigan knew that I was beginning to get a little bit tired of research and I'd be happy to get back into the classroom.
And what changed my attitude was that those two courses, the classroom courses that I taught at Michigan,
which was just an accident, just a coincidence.
When I did that, I said, never again.
I'm never going to do another bit of research.
If I can't get a teaching job, I just quit, period.
Well, this turned out to be a teaching job, at least I thought it was.
So I wrote him a letter, and I talked to Crawford on the telephone.
We talked one Monday.
And he described the job, and it sounded good to me.
And he mentioned the salary, which was about what I was getting in Michigan.
And I expressed some interest in it.
And he says, well, how soon can you be here?
I said, school starts next Monday.
That was just a week away.
Next Monday?
And he says, yeah.
And I says, hesitate a little bit.
And I says, I'll be there on Friday.
So I met Crawford at the bus station up here Friday of that week and started teaching the following Monday.
How long did it take you to get your belongings made?
I packed a suitcase, and that's all it was.
I left everything else.
Didn't bring the family.
I left everything else.
Oh, I see.
You finally stayed in Michigan for a while.
Our children were in high school there, and there wasn't any question about bringing the family.
They had to stay there and finish high school.
And my wife was pleasant enough about it.
She agreed.
And since she knew that I wanted the job, she couldn't object.
So she just says, go on.
Get off.
We'll take care of it.
Late January.
After the first term of school stopped in Lexington, and our children could then leave.
Between terms, you see.
Your family didn't go to Michigan?
No, no, the family stayed in Lexington while I was in Michigan.
See, this was just a temporary thing up there in Michigan.
Oh, I see.
No thought ever of my being there permanently.
I knew that.
Everybody knew that.
This was a special job that I was doing with this friend of mine for the Army Ordinance Department.
And the only reason at all that I went was... Well, there were two reasons.
The first place was the salary.
I had...
gotten, like everybody else there, I received a cut during the Depression.
And if I had stayed in the engineering college, I probably would have advanced money-wise.
But since I was in the agricultural college, where the salaries were not quite up to what I had enjoyed in the engineering college, I was pressed a little bit salary-wise.
So when they offered me almost twice what I was making there in Kentucky, I just jumped at it just like that.
What were your impressions of coming to Texas compared to what you'd been used to in Kentucky and Michigan?
What kind of experience was it to move that far?
You mean in the department, department-wise?
No, I mean just generally.
I had never been to Texas, so I didn't know anything about it from personal experience.
I had read about the University of Texas and a little bit about Texas A&M University and oil industry in Houston and so forth and so on.
So I wasn't ignorant of the state, but I'd never visited it.
And I rode a train from Lexington
to Louisville, to Dallas.
Train got in late in Dallas.
I missed my train that morning to College Station.
So I was going to have to wait all day in Dallas for another train.
So I got the bright idea about a bus.
I saw something about a bus.
So I thought, I'm going to just get on this bus and ride to College Station instead of waiting all day in Dallas.
Longest bus ride I ever had in all my life.
Stopped at every crossroad between Dallas and College Station.
I got in here at 7 o'clock.
If I had waited and caught the train out of Dallas, I'd have had a nice pleasant stay in Dallas and gotten here at 8 o'clock.
Professor Crawford met me and he took me to his home where I stayed all night.
And the next day, which was Saturday,
recommended that I go up around North Gate here and look for a room, and I did find a boarding house up there at the North Gate where I lived until my family got here.
That wasn't the question you asked.
What was it you asked?
Well, wait, if you asked about how I like Texas or something to that effect, well, I'll tell you and I'll tell everybody else, there's no better place in Texas to live than College Station.

of the gulf so you get away from all of that hurricane high moisture area storms and so forth from the gulf you're far enough south so you got away from all of those northers that run through there north waco around dallas and fort worth you're far enough west so you get away from all that swampy area over there in east texas western louisiana
And you're far enough east so you can get away from all the sandstorms in West Texas.
So where else can you live that's any better than College Station?
I tell everybody that.
So I've been happy here as far as that is concerned.
What did your wife think of when she came here?
I beg your pardon?
What did your wife think of moving to Texas?
She just accepted it.
She's always been a good wife, good mother.
And she fitted in here just fine.
She was a very pleasant individual.
She started going to meeting the wives and going to bridge parties and women's social clubs and church activities and things of that sort.
It seems to have fit in here very well.
Was College Station very much different from Lexington in those days?
Oh yes, quite a bit different.
College Station was a country town when I came here.
And that's one of the things I've hated to see change.
It's grown into a small, gaudy, bocce, pothole city.
It was a nice country town when I came here in the fall of 48.
You go from here to Bryan, you drove through a wooded area.
You didn't see a house except every quarter of a mile or something like that.
It's changed tremendously.
When has the most tremendous change occurred since you've been here?
Well, the biggest change came, of course, after Sputnik in 57.
Up to that time, 57, things...
I changed gradually, the enrollment increased, there was more building, faculty increased, and so forth and so on.
When I came here in 48, I contacted Culpeper Realty Company, looking for a place to buy, for my family to live in.
Their agent could not show me one house in Brazos County
that I could buy that wasn't an old house either run down so that the builder was trying to sell it or else it was rented at a normal price and lived in by tenants.
There were two little two-bedroom houses over there on the east side across the highway that were built by two
lumbermen who came from East Texas over here and built them, thinking that, well, they would be able to sell them at a profit.
And they didn't sell them.
They were finished in the summertime before I got here.
I looked at them in September when they were first shown to me.
And they stayed there through October and November and December.
Long, I think, is about maybe the latter part of December.
After I'd gotten prices quoted to me and so forth, I stepped in the Culpepper's office and told them, I said, I'll give you so many thousand dollars for those two houses and the two extra lots.
And they were surprised.
So, well, he says, we'll have to talk to the owners.
So they wrote to the owners in East Texas and right like that, they came back and accepted it.
They'd been trying to sell those houses for two or three months.
So I bought two small two-bedroom houses, one-bath houses, on four lots.
There's a house, a vacant lot, a house, and a vacant lot.
And that's where I moved my family.
They moved into that when they came here in the latter part of January.
You moved into one of the two houses?
Well, we lived in one house, and I rented the other.
I see.
We had moved out of a five-bedroom house in Lexington, Kentucky.
Moved all of our furniture here.
We had more furniture than we needed for two houses.
So the only thing extra I had to buy was a stove for the kitchen and a refrigerator for the kitchen.
Everything else we had.
We just split between the two houses.
I rented one house.
I could have bought the whole thing outright for the money I got for our property in Lexington, but I decided that this was a
Federal Housing Administration or something of the sort.
FHA loans were very popular in those days, and about 4% or 5% interest, something like that.
So I decided to just take out a loan, and I did that.
And the rent that I got from this second house paid for the loan.
My experience here on this campus has been very, very pleasant.
I've enjoyed every minute of it.
You see, because I had a good job doing what I wanted to do.
It was all, no research whatsoever.
That's another story.
As you talk about 1948-64 here, 1948-1964,
I was on the teaching staff doing nothing but teaching.
You did no research at all during that time?
Didn't what?
Did you do any research at all while you were A&M?
Absolutely none.
None?
No.
The only way I was concerned in the least bit with research was when I had graduate students who, and I didn't have very few of those because I didn't care for them.
What did you teach during the years that you were at A&M?
I always say I taught thermodynamics.
That's really the only thing I ever taught was thermodynamics.
But I also had other responsibilities.
I had courses in refrigeration, which is 95% thermodynamics.
I had courses in air conditioning, which is 95% thermodynamics.
And then after a while, Professor Crawford gave me
a problem course that he taught to freshmen, which I enjoyed.
But for the most part, ever since I've been here, I've been concerned with thermodynamics.
I don't know whether you know what thermodynamics is.
In the broad sense, it's defined as the science of energy, which means it includes everything.
So there isn't anything that goes on that isn't concerned with energy in one way or another.
But specifically, thermodynamics is concerned with the transformation of one form of energy into another form of energy, in particular, heat energy into mechanical energy.
That's what thermodynamics is really all about.
But you can go over to the chemistry department and get a course in thermodynamics.
There, they are concerned with heat transfer

energy transformations in chemical processes, whereas I was concerned chiefly with the generation of power, use of gas, oil, coal, to produce heat, to make steam, to produce power, just like you have in a power plant here.
That was the kind of work that I was primarily concerned with way back with the U.S. Steel Corporation.
Were you teaching a separate course in air conditioning?
I had the only course in air conditioning.
It was just one scheduled class in air conditioning.
When was this taught?
Well, they started teaching it before I came here.
I just took over.
You taught it the whole time you were here?
I just took over from another professor who had been doing this work and carried on.
I taught the course up until I went on modified service in 1959.
You don't remember that modified service?
That's between 65 and 70.
Yeah.
You taught three-fifths of time, three-fifths pay for three years, and then half pay for two years.
And when you reached 70, you were out.
Did you do any research in air conditioning while you were teaching the schools?
Here?
No.
As I say, all of my research, most of my research was done between 1920 and 1948.
I quit research after I came here to get away from the search.
I can't get that across to anybody.
Why did you become disillusioned with research?
Because of the length of time that it takes to put into it?
The only instruments I ever used were temperature and pressure measurement instruments.
Every conceivable means of measuring pressure I was familiar with.
Every conceivable means of measuring temperature I was familiar with.
I never did any kind of research that didn't involve sticking thermometers and pressure gauges on some kind of equipment.
And when you do that for how long, 30 years more or less, you get darn tired of it, period.
I saw two things happen.
The research work was getting to be more and more less experimental, which was the kind I was familiar with, and more and more mathematical.
In the old days, when I started out and kept it up for years, if you had an engineering problem, you'd go out to the laboratory and you'd set up some equipment.
and you run an experiment, take some data, and then you go back to your desk, you start studying it, you plot some curves and so forth, and you find out the solution to the problem.
You don't do that today.
Today, the college professor will sit down at his desk and start using matrix algebra and tensor calculus and differential equations, analyzing the problem from a mathematical point of view.
And he may never go into the laboratory.
And he writes that all up and gives to whoever is paid for the research.

And once in a while, you'll find some parameter of some sort where you'll have to go into the laboratory and run an experiment to find the value of it before you can substitute in these equations you see to get your result.
We have men over there in the ME department, and I guess all over the campus,
whose own research consists of mathematics, 99% mathematics, although it will pertain to some kind of mechanical or engineering or other problem.
Well, I hadn't trained myself for that kind of research, the mathematical aspect.
If I'd have stayed in research here, I would continue to work in the laboratory, which I was trying to get away from.
Now, the other thing that I saw happening was the shift from that old-fashioned means of measuring pressure and temperature that I was using to modern electronics.
I came here, I was 54 years old.
And I couldn't see myself trying to learn electronics.
That was for the next generation.
I was going to get out of research completely and turn it over to the next generation.
I don't know whether that makes sense or not.
Before you came to A&M, did you do any research in air conditioning?
In a way, in a broad sense.
such things as fans, which are essential for most air conditioning systems.
I ran tests on heating coils.
What was the first air condition?
Heat air with steam condensing in coils.
And I made tests on unit heaters, which was a kind of
self-contained air conditioning as you stick under windows and blow in air from outside, blow it into the room, and you heat it or you cool it or you humidify it and so forth.
That's air conditioning.
But I never did any kind of research on the kind of air conditioning that you would put in, say, Zachary Engineering Building or the Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles
or some office building in Houston, which would run into thousands of tons of refrigeration and millions of dollars.
I never did that kind of research.
My research was detailed research that you could, where you could set up an experiment in the laboratory, take the data, analyze the results, write a paper, and so forth.
I've written, I don't know,
dozens more papers that have been published on the research that I've done in that general field.
I run tests on the steam boilers, small steam boilers such as you put in buildings which supply steam for air conditioning heating systems.
And I ran a test on small underfeed stokers
which are used, and some of them as small as for private residences, which often turned out to be part of a larger heating, ventilating, air conditioning system.
See, air conditioning itself is sort of a vague term.
It embraces a lot of things.
It's just not

and ashtray conditioning includes not only control of temperature, humidity, air motion, circulation of the air, cleanliness of the air, and I don't know how many other things, at least five separate aspects of what we talk about air conditioning.
Now to one manufacturer air conditioning may mean nothing more than just
Maybe washing or filtering the air, something like that, equipment of that sort.
Another manufacturer, his air conditioning may include just the coils that the air runs through to heat it or cool it.
Another might be just fans.
I run tests on fans.
When did you run these tests regarding air conditioning?
When was this done, your tests on air conditioning?
The kind I'm talking about?
I don't think I want to answer that.
I'll start not at the beginning, but later on.
I'll start, say, with 1920.
Do you know when the first air conditioning was invented?
Do you happen to know?

Well, I followed the development of air conditioning all the way from the time I entered college as a freshman in 1911, when nobody ever heard of the term, right on up until the present day, you might say.
air conditioning developed over a period of 100 years, and in particularly a period of the last 75 years.
From the standpoint of the kind of air conditioning that you write about and read about in textbooks, which is taught in schools today, that kind of air conditioning started
around 1901 or 1902, and gradually developed over the years.
There was what can be referred to as earlier beginnings that go back decades.
But they were all crude inventions of one sort or another.
But the air conditioning profession
Carrier, Carrier Air Conditioning Corporation.
He's known as the father of air conditioning.
And he worked with the Buffalo Forge Company.
He graduated from Cornell in I guess 1901.
And he started working at the Buffalo Forge Company in that same year.
He was born in some western New York town not far from Buffalo City.
So this was a natural place for him to start.
He was a farm boy to start with.
At that time, Buffalo Forge Company didn't make anything other than fans, I think, just air blowing equipment.
Fans were used for supplying ventilation air to rooms and so forth, and for heating and so on.
You had to have fans to move the air, so you talk about fans just like you talk about a locomotive or a train, you see.
It's one of those essential things.
And that's where he got his start.
And he kept adding on, adding on, building on to that, learning more about air.
and its practical uses in various industries, textile, paper, and tobacco industry, and finally into human comfort, hotels, and dining cars, and places like that.
It has had a slow, gradual growth throughout the years, right up to the present time.
If you want to know something about modern air conditioning, say since 1964, or even about 1959, you better get some young fellow over there in the A&E department to tell you about it.
Because my experience all went way back in those early days.
Let me change the subject slightly.
What was the change that you saw at Texas A&M
It's a continuation of the same change that I talked about a little bit ago.

The faculty losing control and the emphasis changing from seeing the students were taught the proper subjects compared to how in the hell are you going to get the money to pay the staff to teach those subjects.
I don't know whether that makes sense to you or not, but it's a switch
from education per se to the monetary aspects.

Now, if there's any one thing that I object to in those 16 years that I've taught here between 1948 and 64, I considered myself primarily a teacher, always knew that I was never going to get rich teaching.
That's the only thing I ever wanted to do was to teach.
There's nothing I like to do better than stand up behind a desk in front of a group of students and tell them something that I think they ought to know.
I get more kick out of that than anything I've ever done in all my life.
That's the only thing.
I didn't know that until I started teaching.
But after I did that, I knew that was the only thing I'd ever wanted to do in all my life.
And I think I got that from my father and mother.
My father was a physician who was a country doctor who never got paid for more than half of the work that he did from patients.
When I looked over his books when he died, there were tens of thousands of dollars of accounts that had never been paid.
He was just a kind old gentleman, country doctor,
who would wait on anybody and charge them almost nothing.
My brother-in-law was sitting in his office, outside his office one day, and he had a couple in his office.
My father had a couple in the waiting room.
And when they got through and the patient was leaving, he asked my father, he says, how much do I owe you?
And my father said, 75 cents.
Man paid the 75 cents, took it out of his pocket, found three quarters, I guess it was, gave him 75 cents.
My father came out of the office into this ante room where my brother-in-law was sitting.
My brother-in-law heard the whole thing.
He says, Doc, what do you mean charging that man 75 cents?
Well, he says, I knew that fellow.
If I'd have said a dollar and a half, he'd have said charge it and I never got another penny.
That's the kind of man he was.
My mother was an ardent church-going person.
There was various women church organizations, WCTU, and I don't know what.
She was involved with all of those things.
My father was a lay preacher.
He'd get out into the county and country churches and deliver sermons.
He taught Sunday school class.
What church?
This was a Christian church, the Disciples of Christ.
or sometime known as Campbellite.
So that was the kind of home environment that I was raised up in.
So I never had any ambition to make a million dollars.
My only ambition was, I didn't understand this, now you understand.
This was all just stuff that I absorbed unconsciously.
But I know now.
for people, just like my father and mother were doing.
And somehow or another, I translated that in terms of teaching, getting up in front of young people and telling them history and so forth.
And that's the only thing I've ever wanted to do all my life.
And nothing would suit me better right now than you to take me out here and put me behind a desk and talk to a dozen people, you see.
Just the way I'm talking to you now.
That's what I've always wanted to do.
Well, what were some of the changes that occurred in regard to student violence?
Obviously, you've got to go back through the 50s and 60s and 70s and talk about hippies and student demonstrations and everything of that sort.
I grew up in that period, just like you did and everybody else.
When I came here in 48, it was the war atmosphere, or rather the war being over type of atmosphere, getting away
from hard duties such as demanded of people in the Army and concentrating on learning something so that you could get out into the profession and make a living.
That was the whole attitude.
The attitude among the students that I saw
here after 48, nearly 30 years, was getting a job.
Just becoming proficient in something so that they could get a job, hold down their job.
Now they were not looking for shortcut ways of getting out of doing something on campus.
and having somebody give them a job just because they had a degree, they were actually interested in learning something.
You'd get up in front of a group of students in the classroom and you got the impression that they wanted to learn what was in the textbook and what you wanted to teach them.
That gradually, over a period of those 16 years, and maybe it's still going on, changed to
that damn degree in any way you can, whether you learn anything or not, and get out there and get this job.
It's emphasis on the job and using the degree as a ticket to get the job.
That was the thing that became important.
Now, when did that change take place?
I'll give you one guess.
It was when Sputnik was launched.
The whole nation practically panicked.
Look what the Russians have done.
They put this thing up there in the sky.
They can start bombing the whole nation any time they wish.
We're all doomed to destruction.
What are we going to do about it?
And on the campus, that reaction was that we've got to get some new people, bring in some new high-powered instructors from outside at any price.
got to increase the staff, increase the quality of the staff.
That's the important.
So that we bring ourselves up to where we're even with the Russians and start developing this new technology.
Do you remember anything about the Committee of 100 or something like that?
That began
shortly after 1957, the AAUP and other organizations on this campus started what they called the The American Association of University Professors.
Yeah.
What did thatit was the Committee of 100.
Their idea was to go out in the state and find businessmen and other people who they thought was interested in education and had influence among people who owned oil wells and other property.
And let's start a new program on this campus here which would enhance education
bring it up to a higher standard, increase the quality and so forth, so that we could compete with the Russians.
That was the big change that took place.
Now you can, you yourself and everybody else, can put your own experience in that attitude, a switch from knowledge itself
to position.
Using your position to advance regardless of your knowledge.
I'm not saying that exactly right, but you get the point, I'm sure.
That kept up and is still going on.
I'll go back to the moment ago.
We were talking about bringing people in from outside
And when Dean Calhoun came here.
First name?
Dean Calhoun.
He is the chancellor or whatever he is.
He came here as dean of engineering about 55, 56.
Do you remember his first name?
Hmm?
Do you remember his first name?
Calhoun.
Oh gosh, just look it up in the catalog.
I should remember his name.
I was on a committee of staff that met once a month.
And about once a semester,
we would invite the dean of engineering to come talk to us.
And I remember Dean Calhoun was the dean, and he was talking to us on various topics.
And now he says, you know, we're going to have to go out and find men of high quality and bring them here.
put them on our staff in order to improve the quality of our staff.
That's an insult to anybody on this staff.
What's wrong with the quality now?
Anyhow, that's what he said, you see.
And to improve the quality of our staff, we got to go out and bring people in.
He didn't say any particular university, but he was thinking about Harvard and Yale and Princeton.
Chicago and other places, bringing faculty.
Now he says, of course we're going to have to pay them more than we're paying you now.
Everybody just absolutely quiet, no reaction.
And he went on talking.
After a few minutes I spoke up and I said, it looks to me like the only way you get ahead in this
business is to change your position.
Oh, no.
He just almost panicked.
He could just see everybody in the room, everybody on campus, everybody, staff member in the engineering corner getting up and going someplace looking for a position.
He was losing his whole staff.
Oh, no, no, no.
I said, you just got through telling us about bringing in these people from outside, bringing them here and paying us more than you're paying us now.
I didn't tell him this, but he got the implication.
He had just come here to be dean, enhancing his position at a higher salary.
If there's anything I object to over the past 5, 10, 15, 20 years, is my training a student and sending them out into industry
